info: Revenue from this distributor represented at most 10% of total revenue.

Equity component balances (common stock, additional paid‑in capital, retained earnings and accumulated other comprehensive income) remain unchanged at 6,281 units across all reporting dates from 2022‑10‑29 through 2025‑11‑01, indicating a static capital structure during this period.

The excerpt lists accrued liabilities, interest‑rate swaps, senior notes with various maturity dates through 2054, fair‑value inputs for money‑market funds, corporate and bank obligations, and revenue concentration for distributors across 2022‑2024.
Multiple line items across periods show the same reported amount of 6,281, indicating placeholder or uniform reporting with no disclosed variation.

The filing discloses fair‑value hierarchy (Level 1 and Level 2) for unit trust funds, equity securities, fixed‑income securities, defined‑benefit plan real estate, pooled funds and cash equivalents for periods ending November 2024 and November 2025, and mentions revolving credit facilities, senior notes (2028, 2030, 2025) and commercial paper.

Analog Devices filed its 2025 Form 10‑K as a large accelerated filer, confirming compliance with reporting and internal‑control requirements. The company reported a non‑affiliate market equity value of approximately $81.1 billion and 489,654,097 shares of common stock outstanding as of November 1, 2025.

Analog Devices highlights its strategy of capital efficiency, R&D‑driven innovation and acquisitions to deliver high‑performance analog, mixed‑signal, power and RF ICs for Intelligent Edge applications. The company leverages AI‑enabled software platforms (CodeFusion Studio 2.0, Power Studio) and deep customer relationships, supported by roughly 13,000 engineers and a global sales footprint in about 50 countries. Its product portfolio spans over 75,000 SKUs across industrial, automotive, consumer and communications markets, with revenue composition shifting toward industrial (≈45% FY25) and automotive (≈30% FY25).

The company serves diverse high‑growth markets—including instrumentation, aerospace/defense, healthcare, energy, automotive, communications and consumer—leveraging its high‑performance analog, mixed‑signal and power ICs while noting competitive pressures, supply‑chain constraints, seasonal demand and reliance on third‑party foundries; it emphasizes a strong IP position with about 4,780 U.S. patents and 500 pending applications, a workforce of roughly 24,500 employees (13,000 engineers) with disclosed gender diversity metrics, and ongoing ESG initiatives with ISO‑14001 and ISO‑45001 certifications.

The company employed approximately 24,500 staff as of November 1 2025, including about 13,000 engineers; the workforce is 60% male, senior leadership 73% male, managers 75% male, and 40% of the board female, with a voluntary turnover rate of roughly 7.2% for fiscal 2025. Distributors contributed about 56% of revenue. The firm emphasizes extensive international operations and outlines significant geopolitical, trade, supply‑chain and regulatory risks—such as tariffs, export controls, currency and credit market volatility, and reliance on third‑party wafer foundries and distributors—that could materially impact its results.

Company highlights extensive risks that could cause material fluctuations in revenue, margins and earnings, including macroeconomic and geopolitical pressures, inflation and higher interest rates, variable customer demand and order cancellations, supply‑chain constraints, tax and regulatory changes, sanctions, manufacturing yield issues, talent retention challenges, acquisition integration risks, cybersecurity and AI‑related vulnerabilities, intellectual‑property exposure, and evolving privacy and AI regulations.

Significant risks highlighted include extensive data‑privacy and cybersecurity obligations under GDPR, CCPA and other laws; ongoing litigation and intellectual‑property disputes; ESG and environmental‑health‑safety compliance pressures; tax audit exposures and potential increases in effective tax rate; reliance on U.S. government contracts with stringent security and procurement rules; a large debt load of $8.6 billion plus $446.6 million short‑term commercial paper and ability to incur $2.6 billion additional indebtedness, with covenant constraints; green‑financing commitments tied to $750 million sustainability‑linked notes that could affect reputation if targets are missed; and potential cash‑flow strain requiring earnings repatriation.

The company highlighted exposure to green‑financing performance risk tied to $750 million sustainability‑linked notes, noting potential reputational damage and cash‑flow impacts if targets are missed. It also warned that insufficient U.S. cash could force foreign earnings repatriation and extra taxes. Natural‑disaster and climate‑change threats to semiconductor supply chains were noted, as were typical semiconductor stock‑price volatility drivers. Cybersecurity governance is described, with no material incidents in recent years. The firm disclosed a dividend of $0.99 per share (≈$484.8 million total) and continued aggressive share‑repurchase activity (≈216.5 million shares for $17 billion).

The company reported a 17% revenue increase to $11.0 billion (in thousands) in FY2025 driven by growth across industrial, automotive, consumer and communications markets, with gross margin improving to 61.5%. Net income rose 39% to $2.27 billion and diluted EPS increased 39% to $4.56. A cash dividend of $0.99 per share, totaling about $484.8 million, was declared. Share repurchases to date total 216.5 million shares for $17.0 billion, with $9.7 billion still authorized. The stock price was $234.13 and there were 2,142 record holders.

Fiscal 2025 revenue grew 17% to $11.0M, with gains in every region—especially a 161% surge in Rest of North/South America and 34% in China—while gross margin rose to 61.5% (up 440 bps). R&D and SG&A expenses increased 19% and 17% respectively, staying at 16% and 11% of revenue; amortization slipped slightly, special charges jumped 88% due to global repositioning, and non‑operating expense fell 14% as interest income rose.

Net income rose sharply in FY2025 driven by a $899.7M operating income increase and lower non‑operating expense, while provision for taxes grew due to a $153.8M deferred tax charge, resulting in an effective tax rate of 16.4% versus 8.0% a year earlier. Cash and equivalents reached $3.7B (US $2.4B) with strong operating cash flow of $4.81M, supporting a $0.99 per share dividend ($484.8M total) and a $9.7B remaining capacity under a $26.7B stock repurchase authorization. The company remains compliant with its $3.0B revolving credit facility covenant, carries $8.1B senior notes and $446.6M commercial paper, and plans $533.6M capex in FY2025. Current liabilities rose to $3.2B.

The company reports $199.7 million of uncertain tax positions, notes that interest expense would rise about $14.5 million (2025) and $15.5 million (2024) per 100‑basis‑point rate increase, while interest income would increase about $36.5 million (2025) and $19.9 million (2024). Fixed‑for‑floating swaps total $1.0 billion notional with a $12.6 million fair value and would increase swap payable by $45.9 million under a 100‑bp rise. Senior unsecured notes total $8.2 billion principal at $7.5 billion fair value, and commercial paper balances are $446.6 million.

The company performed interest‑rate and foreign‑currency sensitivity analyses showing that a 100‑basis‑point rise would increase interest income by $36.5 million (2025) and $19.9 million (2024) and raise the fair‑value of a $1.0 billion fixed‑for‑floating swap payable by $45.9 million. Senior unsecured notes of $8.2 billion (fair value $7.5 billion) and $446.6 million of commercial paper were outstanding as of 1 Nov 2025. A 10% adverse Euro movement would cause $89.6 million loss (2025) and $32.2 million loss (2024). Forward‑exchange contracts had a fair value of –$1,267 (2025) and –$8,961 (2024); a 10% adverse move would increase their value to $47,703 (2025) and $31,564 (2024) and a favorable move would create liabilities of –$45,730 (2025) and –$45,922 (2024). The sensitivity analysis indicated no material impact on the overall portfolio fair value.

Revenue fell from $12.3 bn in 2023 to $9.4 bn in 2024 before rising to $11.0 bn in 2025; net income and EPS showed the same pattern, declining from $3.31 bn (EPS $6.60) in 2023 to $1.64 bn (EPS $3.30) in 2024 and partially recovering to $2.27 bn (EPS $4.59) in 2025. Total assets edged lower while liabilities rose, reducing shareholders’ equity to $33.8 bn. The audit highlighted testing of controls over price‑protection credit estimates.

Analog Devices reported net income of $3.31 billion in 2023, falling to $1.64 billion in 2024 before rebounding to $2.27 billion in 2025. The Board increased the quarterly dividend each year to $3.34, $3.62 and $3.89 per share, while continuing share repurchases, totaling 16,474 shares in 2023, 3,181 in 2024 and 9,448 in 2025. Operating cash flow remained strong, above $4.8 billion in 2023 and 2025, and $3.85 billion in 2024. The company financed growth with new debt issuances of $1.09 billion in 2024 and $1.49 billion in 2025, and leveraged commercial paper programs of $5.29 billion (2023), $10.18 billion (2024) and $9.46 billion (2025). Investing activities reflected continued capital expenditures and short‑term investment purchases, leading to net cash outflows of roughly $1.27‑$1.32 billion each year. Cash balances grew to $2.5 billion at year‑end 2025.

Cash and cash equivalents fell slightly year‑over‑year while total cash (including short‑term investments) rose to $2.5 bn in 2025; short‑term investments grew markedly. Inventories increased to $1.66 bn. Net PP&E declined to $3.32 bn. Goodwill remained essentially unchanged with no impairment. The company identified a Malaysia facility as held‑for‑sale, reclassifying $54.2 m without a write‑down. Fiscal 2024 included an extra week, affecting comparability.

Goodwill remained essentially unchanged with a small $35,405 acquisition in 2025; intangible assets total $18.0 million (gross) with customer relationships and technology-based assets comprising the bulk, and accumulated amortization rising to $10.0 million. Amortization expense declined to $1.6 billion in 2025 from $1.7 billion in 2024 and $2.0 billion in 2023, with modest annual forecasts through 2030. CHIPS Act grant offsets reduced current tax payable by $96.3 million and added $167.2 million to other assets in 2025 (versus $106.3 million and $174.5 million in 2024). Foreign‑currency hedging notional amounts increased to $297 million (2025) from $257 million (2024), with fair‑value holdings of a few thousand dollars. Undesignated hedge notional amounts also rose, with fair‑value balances shifting. The company employed interest‑rate swaps to convert $1 billion of 2.1% senior notes to floating rate, recording offsetting gains/losses. Credit risk from counterparties is deemed non‑material. Cash excluded from fair‑value tables remained $1.4 billion.

The company outlines its fair‑value hierarchy (Level 1‑3) and reports fair‑value measurements for assets and liabilities as of Nov 1 2025 and Nov 2 2024, including cash excluded ($1.4 bn each), government money‑market funds, corporate and bank obligations, forward foreign‑currency contracts, deferred‑compensation investments and interest‑rate derivatives. Total assets measured at fair value were $2.403 bn in 2025 and $1.064 bn in 2024; total liabilities measured at fair value were $20.5 m and $53.1 m respectively. Amortized cost of available‑for‑sale securities and fair values of commercial paper notes are also disclosed.

Company disclosed fair‑value methods for cash equivalents, derivatives and debt; maintains a $8.2 bn principal debt portfolio with various senior notes and $447 m commercial paper (2025) and $548 m (2024). Distributor sales were $6.1 bn (2025) and $5.5 bn (2024) with credit liabilities of $785 m and $509 m. AOCI showed net losses of $185 m (2024) and $155 m (2025). Credit risk is concentrated in high‑quality cash equivalents and major distributors; supply‑chain risk noted from reliance on limited wafer suppliers.

The company reclassified significant amounts out of AOCI in 2025 and 2024, including positive currency forward gains, large interest‑rate derivative gains, and related tax impacts, resulting in net reclassification totals of $16.647 million and $9.060 million respectively. Net income fell from $3.315 million in 2023 to $2.267 million in 2025, with basic EPS decreasing from $6.60 to $4.59 and diluted EPS from $6.55 to $4.56. Anti‑dilutive stock options were modest. The 2020 Equity Incentive Plan authorizes 21.2 million shares, with 11.6 million remaining available, and the ESPP has 3.7 million shares available. A 5% annual forfeiture rate is applied to unvested awards. The company highlighted ongoing tax uncertainty, adoption of new accounting pronouncements (ASU 2023‑07, ASU 2023‑09, ASU 2024‑03), and disclosed stock‑based compensation methodology.

Stock-based compensation expense increased to $321.6 million in fiscal 2025, with a 5% annual forfeiture rate applied. The ESPP had 3.7 million shares available for future grants as of Nov 1 2025. Options outstanding fell to 1.197 million with an average exercise price of $115.14 and aggregate intrinsic value of $142.4 million; intrinsic value of exercised options declined to $64.2 million in 2025. Restricted stock units total unrecognized compensation cost of $640.2 million, with $345.1 million of grant‑date fair value vesting in 2025. The company repurchased 216.5 million shares for $17.0 billion, leaving $9.7 billion still authorized. Revenue grew to $11.0 billion in 2025 (up from $9.4 billion in 2024) with net income rising to $2.27 billion. End‑market mix shifted, with industrial revenue share decreasing to 45% and communications rising to 13% of total.

Revenue declined from $12.3M in 2023 to $9.4M in 2024 before rebounding to $11.0M in 2025, with distributors remaining the primary channel (56‑61% of sales) and direct customers contributing 37‑43%; U.S. sales represent roughly one‑third of total, while Europe and China are the largest foreign markets, and total property, plant and equipment modestly increased to $3.32M in 2025 as management monitors macro conditions and special charge liabilities.

The company reported cumulative special charges of $591.6 million for global repositioning and $155.9 million for its Q4 2023 re‑organization plan, reflecting workforce reductions and related severance, benefit and IP write‑off costs. Accrued liabilities are detailed for 2024 and 2025, with total accrued liabilities rising to $1.645 million in 2025 from $1.106 million in 2024, and components such as distributor price adjustments, compensation, lease and tax accruals showing modest changes.

Accrued liabilities rose to $1.65 billion in 2025 from $1.11 billion in 2024, driven by higher distributor price adjustments and compensation accruals. Sublease income increased to $15 million in 2025 versus $12.8 million in 2024. Operating lease right‑of‑use assets declined slightly, while lease liabilities remain about $0.36 billion present value with $394.9 million of future payments. Defined contribution plan expense was $74.9 million in 2025 and defined benefit pension/post‑retirement expense grew to $71.2 million. Net periodic benefit cost for 2025 was $19.2 million. Pension plan funded status remains negative at approximately $(100 million).

Analog Devices reported net losses of $12.4M (2025) and $25.9M (2024) with additional AOCI losses, and highlighted pension and postretirement benefit obligations totaling $127.2M (2025) and $132.7M (2024). Projected benefit obligations exceed plan assets, and assumptions include discount rates around 5.7% and compensation growth near 5.8%. Expected 2026 company contribution to pension plans is $9.4M, with benefit payments rising to $9.3M by 2028. Income tax provision increased to $444.8M in 2025, driven by higher statutory tax and one‑time items.

Income before taxes fell to $2.71 billion in 2025 from $3.61 billion in 2023, driven by lower domestic earnings; the provision for income taxes was $445 million in 2025, reflecting a $153.8 million net deferred tax expense from GILTI remeasurement and a prior $81.7 million discrete benefit in 2023. The company holds $33.6 billion of unrecognized deferred tax on outside‑basis differences and $166.2 million of unrealized tax benefits that could decline by up to $150 million pending audit outcomes. An IRS assessment of $267 million for fiscal 2018‑2019 is being contested. The firm secured a $3.0 billion revolving credit facility (no borrowings as of 11/1/2025) and issued $1.5 billion of senior notes ($850 million 4.250% due 2028 and $650 million 4.500% due 2030).

Debt increased to $8.59 bn in 2025 from $7.58 bn in 2024, with total long‑term debt rising to $8.22 bn and short‑term debt remaining modest. The company declared a $0.99 per share cash dividend totaling about $484.8 m and confirmed compliance with all debt covenants.

The filing lists the consolidated financial statements (income, comprehensive income, balance sheet, shareholders’ equity, cash flow) for FY2025, 2024 and 2023 and enumerates many exhibits covering amended articles, by‑laws, multiple debt indentures, and various equity incentive and deferred compensation plans.

The filing lists numerous exhibit filings for various stock option, restricted stock unit, and performance‑based equity agreements under the 2020 Equity Incentive Plan and earlier incentive plans, indicating ongoing use of equity compensation mechanisms.

Valuation allowance for deferred tax assets declined sharply in 2025, dropping to $263.9 million (263875 in thousands) from $343.1 million the prior year after a $79.2 million reduction, following a $10.6 million increase in 2024; the filing also references a new credit agreement and several compensation plan exhibits.
